Award.AbstractNarration:
Seven Worlds is a landmark television series and multi-media project from BBC America and the BBC Natural History Unit, due to broadcast in 2019/2020. In addition to the large U.S. and global reach of the television series, this project promises to have the largest online footprint of any BBC wildlife series to date. This award is for logistic support only for filming marine life with NSF-supported research programs at McMurdo Station, Antarctica during the 2017/2018 polar season. Seven Worlds will engage, inform, and inspire audiences with iconic landscapes, spectacular wildlife, and cutting-edge science. The series will look at the natural history unique to each of the seven continents, and explore how their geographic position and geologic history have influenced the wildlife living there. A key episode is on Antarctica. It will provide an unparalleled opportunity to see how earth system processes and ecosystem dynamics have shaped the extraordinary physical and behavioral adaptions of life forms that manage to survive the extreme cold. It will also showcase scientific discoveries about the world's toughest environment.

This series will reflect the newest iteration of storytelling methods to promote audience engagement and learning of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) content. The BBC Natural History Unit's expertise in emotive and factual storytelling will inform the content and narrative of the deliverables. This allows for a scientifically accurate yet captivating viewer experience that enhances retention of scientific information. In addition, the television series will be complemented with a series of short-form out-reach videos with collaborating scientists to showcase their important work online. BBC landmark wildlife series attract a gender-balanced group of viewers, reach a younger audience, and reach a more diverse audience when compared to other factual programs. With BBC's sizable audience and ability to reach traditionally underserved demographics, the project will promote STEM research to a broad and diverse audience. The intent is to create a platform that not only helps the public understand Antarctic science, but to feel immersed and connected to a place that is distant and remote. Often what is "out of sight is out of mind", but by transporting the public to a place few will ever visit, this film and associated online components will make tangible concepts such as: Antarctic biodiversity, behavioral ecology, biogeography, geomorphology, glaciology, and humanity's role in shaping the future. The project is supported by NSF's Office of Polar Programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW

Seven Worlds is a landmark television wildlife series and multi-media project from BBC America and the BBC Natural History Unit, following on from the highly successful Planet Earth, Frozen Planet, Planet Earth II, and Blue Planet II series. NSF generously provided the filming team with access and field support to accomplish some astonishing filming of a wide variety of species and landscapes in and around McMurdo, Antarctica, as well as the chance to document the fascinating science being conducted at the base, during the 2017/2018 polar season.

 

Seven Worlds will engage, inform, and inspire audiences with iconic landscapes, spectacular wildlife, and cutting-edge science. The series will look at the natural history unique to each of the seven continents, and explore how their geographic position and geologic history have influenced the wildlife living there. A key episode is on Antarctica. It provides an unparalleled opportunity to see how earth system processes and ecosystem dynamics have shaped the extraordinary physical and behavioral adaptions of those that manage to survive the extreme cold. It is also a chance to showcase scientific discoveries made by NSF research in the world’s toughest environment. In particular, 2016 was a landmark year for international cooperation as scientists and governments from around the world came together to create the largest protected area of any kind, the Ross Sea Marine Protected Area (MPA). Our film aims to herald this extraordinary conservation achievement and to show off this pristine and rich ecosystem and the unique marine life that inhabits it. We have covered these stories:

1)     The surprising and extraordinary biodiversity of Antarctic waters.

2)     The astonishing effort that Weddell seal mothers invest in their pups to survive in such an extreme environment, focusing on the vulnerable period straight after a pup is born to when it takes its first swim.

3)     The discovery that an amphipod will hitch a lift on a jellyfish to seek safety against predatory fish.

4)     How icefish have evolved antifreeze proteins that allow them to survive super-cooled waters.

5)     We can discuss the evolution of gigantism in Antarctic invertebrates through observing a gigantic jellyfish being consumed.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This series will reflect the newest iteration of storytelling methods to promote audience engagement and learning of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) content. Story construction will be based around the key themes of characterization, immersion, and factual content. This allows for a scientifically accurate yet captivating viewer experience that enhances retention of scientific information. In addition we have filmed a series of short-form out-reach videos with collaborating NSF scientists to showcase their important work. We have an in-house team of experts at the BBC Digital Unit to help design and implement our online and social media strategy. We have also paired with key scientists from NSF’s Antarctic program to act as scientific advisors for the television series including: Dr. Amy Moran – University of Hawaii, Dr. Jay Rotella – Montana State University, Dr. Stacy Kim – California State University, Dr. Paul Cziko – University of Oregon, and Dr. Andrew Thurber – Oregon State University.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

BBC landmark wildlife series attract a gender-balanced group of viewers (52% female, 48% male), and reach a younger audience (37% under-45), and a more diverse audience (more than double the number of minority viewers) when compared to other factual programs (BBC internal reports, 2012 & 2013). It is estimated that the Planet Earth series reached a US audience of more than 65 million people and over 750 million worldwide. With our sizable audience and ability to reach traditionally underserved demographics, we are able to promote STEM research on a huge scale. The series will first broadcast in the USA in early 2020.
